text: Blindfolded, smith'follows the caravan of Indians through the woods. .

Smith walks down the road to the Jamestown fort. It is just after sunrisa. The English sentries ara fast asleep. The Indians stop a hundred feet away. Smith locks up. The gates are decorated with the skulls of deer and.bear. Wha will stepping back into this other world mean? Will he forget? It seams he goes forward by a conscious act of will,  oo 58
A sentry wakes up. He gasps at the Indian caravan, then a Smith himself -- this man whom they had given up for dead to discover him so utterly changed.
Captain Smith! He goes running through the colony to announce Smith's arrival,

The Savages will have to stop here, Captain. Raasons of security. (under his breath) We don’t want ‘em to know we’re mortal. Smith gestures to the Indians that they should set their gifts down. They are only too glad to leave,

Within the walls of the fort averything is topsy-turvy. Along the street of sailcloth roofs the houses are fallin down, the faw that have been completed. The men limp out ef their tents and dugouts, pale with rickets and dysentery, like the inmates of a concentration camp. Smith finds WILF, the cabin boy, drawing water. His feet are dusty and bleeding. He has bowed legs and sharp, ugly eyes. Yat still he is as swaggaring a boy as ever stood four feat, six inehes tall. He offers Smith a drink.
You have to quaff it now. Somebody else wants the tumbler.
What’s happened here? Where is Captain Newport?
Gone back to England, sir, with all three ships -- to get supplias, new men. He left Captain Ratcliffe in his place.
And Ratcliffa, where is he?
(evasively) Why ~-- he’s gone, sir. We expect he perished. Nobody knows. (MORE)

WILF (contd) I mean, there’s talk about this and that, but nobody knows, in the proper sense of the word. One day he just vanished like a ghost! Ill-looking faces jut out of doors, register amazement, then withdraw inte. the darkness, The dirty juvenile with the manners of a man begins to whisper, worried he will b overheard,

Since you left half of ‘em has diad. Crops all failed. Seeds won’t take root. We got nothing to eat. This morning there’s another four gone. You find them laying out on the doorstep, dogs sniffing them, the ones they still hadn’t set to eatin’. I grew up in Brighton, but I swear before Almighty God, I never seen the like. The gangs, they bully around and steal from the store, gamble and - keep us all on short rations whilst they have their fill. {over such scenes) They don’t fool me. They cuff me about but I just looks at them cold- like, you see. They know what I’m thinking. Hoho! Don’t they imagine I got my own ways of dealing with things? -No, oh no, by no means! He slyly removes a knife from the crown of his hat. Suddenly,

Don’t fret your ayelids on that score! They bowl while the houses fall down. Nobody pays attention or obeys the other’s commands! Be a charmer, don’t noise it about I told you soa. Wingfield walks up and cuffs the boy aside. “| WINGFIELD Winsome boy. I feel about him as though he were my own son. He struts around like a Japanese swordsman, all glower an bluster, backed by six other pirates armed with swords an matchlocks.

You look quite well, Smith. Been anjoying yourself, have you? Been enjoying yourself mightily, I expect.  47. From his regimen of venison and corn, Smith looks shockingly healthy next to tha other Englishmen, evan Wingfield and his henchmen, who have fared better than th rest.
You were sant to relieve our situation, not to pleasure yourself. We here have suffered. {nodding at Wilf) Been telling you a lot of stories, has a?
As a good citizen, I ignore the stories which bring officialdom into disrepute.
No speeches, Smith. Things are differant now, We can’t gat away with cheek. Allow cheek, and we shall have chaos. I -wear a medal now, I am the President. You were stripped of your captaincy.
May I know why?

Someday, yes, but let's not talk about that now. As a matter of fact, you'd be considerably happier if you didn’t make my job more tiring than it already is. You shortly will be arrested in the nama of His Lordship, King James, and confined to the fortress.
What is tha charge against me, if I may know?
Caused tha death of two good Englishmen. Than you deserted. Furthermore, you have allowed the Naturals to see the state of our extremity.
Are you qualified to pass judgment on me?

That needn’t concern you at present. Pity you were not here to defend yourself in person at the trial, I assume your guilt made you afraid to return, He waits to sea if Smith will be provoked into defi but Smith only stares at him. © defiance,
My trial?
You were tried during the period of your desertion.
This does not amuse me,
Then you will be even less amused to learn that you were condemned to death, Crazy with hunger, the English fall madly on Powhatan’s gifts, cheering Smith as a hero. His parakeet flies away.

What did you offer them in return for these bats’ tails and what-have~-you? He gestures contemptuously at Powhatan’s gifts, while his cronies bully the others out of the way to make sure they gat the lion’s share.
Nocturnal creatures! He sticks his sword into a raccoon and throws it to a man to whom ha owas a favor.

(to his henchmen) Send them a dozen of those red top hats. And the bed in which Master Godfrey died, since none will sleep in it. And Nelson’s cur. The ever so poxey one. They haven’t one of those, I suppose. He points to a sickly greyhound. Argall steps forward and speaks directly to Smith, ignering Wingfield. 48.  as.

He keeps the best food for himself, Captain, and gives us rotten corn. Being an atheist, he has no Bible, which you can go down there right now and prove. You'll find he also has a Spanish grammar, for reasons which are unclear, except parhaps to a Papist scholar. Smith studies the motley crew. He has just come from peopla who asked for nothing and gave away everything in return. He feels a disgust with their selfishness, greed and complaint. He sees in tham the person he was four months ago and must never allow himsalf to ba again,

He was planning to take the boat and leave us here while he ran off to Newfoundland. His name is not even Wingfield. Woodson -- Woodson’s the - name, Charming. Left England under a cloud of disgrace, he did. A master forger. Charming in tha extreme. Ever so charming.

Seize them. Anyone impeding the punishment of these rogues will be dealt with harshly. Wingfield’s men move to arrest Smith and Argall. smith draws his sword. They challenge him with theirs, but they are no match, evan in numbers. With dazzling skill, he dispatches three of them. As the crowd sees his strength and the chance to turn the tide of things at the fort, th join him. Wingfield’s man are soon overpowered.

You want to gat rid of me, eh? Give me the old heave-ho? Let ma tell you, thera’s not a square-head here man enough to get away with that. Don’t start anything you can’t finish. Will you all be witnesses to this? Stop now or I shall report this mutiny to London. It could be ugly.

Quite ugly. A sword tip explodes through Wingfield’s armor. Argalil h come up behind him and run him through. Smith stares at Argall, stunned by this naked act of murder.  50. The others seem accustomed to such goings- for the, entertainment. gonngeron and grateful
Dead as a ‘erring, Serve ‘im right. Puttin’ on airs! With a flick of his sword, Smith sends the murd, flying from Argall’s hands. meer weapon
I was only trying to help you.
Arrest this man. A man named Small steps forward.

I can ratify what Mr. Argall said, {toeaing Wingfield) . He refused to give me a chicken or return the whistle I gave him in payment for it. In fact, one morning while conniving with his friend Mr. Ackley here, he even refused to give me a spoonful of beer. Were we in England, I should be ashamed to let my servant keep company with such fellows.

You never had a servant. You were one. I ate a single chicken, and that when I was very ill. Small here ‘as aaten six, a number of which he could not be troubled to cook. For myself I can prove that he begged in Ireland like a regue, without a license. I know his games. [I know the criminal mind. Argall steps forward, swallowing his pride.

I say it’s Captain Smith should lead us. The men raise a cheer of agreement. After all, he has saved them from starvation, Ackley strips the President’s medallion off Wingfield and puts it over Smith’s neck. With a wave of his hand, Smith rescinds the order for Argall’s arrest.  59 60 Sl.

Tf I lead you, you’ll listen to me and respect my orders. The gentlemen will be obliged to bend their backs and obey with the rest. I haven’t had the opportunity to look into it, but it seems that quite a few of you imagine that you’re still in London. 1/11 be a worse tyrant than this man was. (nedding at Wingfield) So make up your minds. We are not going to have an easy time with the Naturals. We are superior to them in arms but not in numbers, nor in character. They are a formidable enemy. Unless we leave by spring, they will attack us. If you don’t put things in order, they will see how great our need is and be tempted to attack before then. It appears we might have picked a poxey spot to land. And you thought you'd come to the land of Cockaigne! But that’s a matter I’11 take up with Captain Newport when he returns. Meanwhile, it will be all wa can do to survive. These gifts will last a month. And soon the snows will fly. But with a united will we can hold out, and shall, What say you, then? The men raise a great cheer. Smith finds himself beaming with pleasure at their approbation. They. snatch up his gifts and carry him off on their shoulders. . INT. PRESIDENT’S OFFICE Smith enters the office reserved for the President of the Colony. There is a bust of King James, a crucifix, a glob and astrolaba -- serious badges of office and English refinement in primitive Jamestown. He caresses them with his hand. Suddenly he laughs out loud. So fortune has tossed him up for'’a while! How long will he ride the wav EXT. JAMESTOWN - MONTAGE, INC POCAHONTAS’ POV Smith walks around the fort, supervising its restoration. New buildings go up: a brickworks, a potter's shed and a pit saw. He is not above rolling up his own sleeves to help in the work, . The men quarrel over everything: building a wall, portion of food, the date of the year.  61 52. (These scenes will be improvised, Smi i disputes in a wisa, clever way. us qualities oe thease leadership make all tha men lock up to him. He continues to wear his unconventional wardrobe -- feather headdress buckskins, war paint. He even insists on sleeping outside on the ground, as he did at Werowocomoco. The routine of his life, hia former thoughts and ambitions, seem futile now, and artificial. What shall he do?
Smith is joking with Ben, Ackley and some of the other me when a fallow with a serious look interrupts him.
What about the gold, Captain?
What do you mean?
Have you told us everything? I mean, : did you see anything that raised your hopes of a better life?
Gold, you mean? What do you care about gold? You're on the verge of starving. This is the most valuable thing I brought you back. He holds out a handful of corn seed.
Who gave it to you? —
A friend.
What about the soil, Captain? Is it good as we thought?

{avoiding their eyes) Not really. In fact, I’ve rarely sean so ill-appearing a pesthole. Look about you. Everything’s gone to swamp, with water standing in lakes and pools, so the ground gives way beneath your feat. I suspect there's more puddles than dry land, producing more mosquitoes in their slime than there are beads in a nunnery -- and each mosquito as hungry as a priest! (MORE)

62 53. SMITH (cont’d) None but a savage could inhabit the place, unless he was a bloody fool or some other manner of ass. But west of here, towards the mountain, or south -- that is somathing else. It still is not clear what line Smith will be able to wal between his duty to the English and his sympathy for the Indians. He looks off toward the woods. The pines sway back and forth in ecstasy.
Smith runs a flag up into the rigging of the shallop and prepares to sat sail. The English wonder at this action.
Where are you going?
(avoiding their eyes) Where you would not dare to follow.
Don’t you think you should take some men with you? It would be dangerous sailing by yourself.
Let them come, if they please. Ackley speaks with Smith privately.
Watch them, sir. They are a dangerous lot.
Are you all right?
To tell the truth, I don’t know how much longer I can last, Captain. I seen too much.
You'll last, my friend. Have hope. Smith boards the shallop and, with a squad of English soldiers, sets out up tha river.
Post a sentry at the point. The rest of you wait for me here. If they come to look at you, leave them alone.  63

He collects a sack of copper hatchets, beads, combs and r hats -~ the English wares most popular with the natives. EXT. DEEP FOREST ~ SMITH’S FOVS Smith stops and looks around. The half-moon has just risen. The trees beckon him on. They seem to run off to the uttermost ends of the earth. His romance with the Indian girl seams far off, unreal. Has he put himself in a false position? What ara his intentions? He almost dreads seaing her -- would it not b almost a relief if she did not appear? -- and yet, when s does not come right away, he feels vexed and disappointed By the confidence with which she walks her path, she convinces him that another way exists than that which his feet have known. She releases his soul from its captivity She breaks up the frozen sea of his heart. He conceives hopes that he never imagined it was in his power to cenceive; the walls of his habitual life fall away and leave him in a wide field, in that new world which he hitherto sought in vain, and which he now knows, not by satting his foot on the Virginia shore, but in the sight her, in her touch, in the joy and grace she radiates. By and by he hears the sound of footsteps. He sees her coming toward him and, in a voice that seems not quite hi he says her name. She seems to look right into him. He never before realized the depth and purity, the touching faithfulness, of her dew-bright eyas. He feels his heart and senses unfolding. She is all simple nature and beauty ag much a part of this October evening as the falling leaves. How should he not take all that she would give him, how not fulfill the spring in her heart and his? Wha did he know of love, until he seized har hand and kissed it? And now -- what does he not know? Their lips seek each other’s, and still they do not speak The moment speach begins all will be unreal.
Why did you come here? She looks up, hurt, amazed.
Sir? You asked me to.
Don’t call me sir, my pretty sweet.
What shall I call you?
John.
What have you sean? Your eyes are like -- stones.

(after a pause) I’ve had nothing but aggravation. Half are sick, the others lunging at each other’s throats like they ware in Brighton Way, They’d do anything for money. They’d risk damnation in this world and the next. And me, a good Man by any lights, moving among such people!
Send them away.

Away? (after a silence) How many lands behind me! How many seas! What blows, dangers! My soul hungered after far horizons. Now there is only this contention with fools, this ignoble war with little things. (pacing) It has always been so. I can naver Stay on land for long. It scorches my feet. It always disappoints. There is comfort and safety in the port, hearthstone and supper, warm blankets, friends. But always I find that I still am not where I must be. Always shut up somewhere. Cut off. Starved.

Look before you. We could live in the woods, I know a place. There is a waterfall there. A bed of moss. I’ve never shown it to anyone. I waited. (caressing his face) My brother will take care of us. He told ma that he would. Make a sign, John. Tell ma if I should keep on. {suddenly alarmed) I wish for you when you’re gone. I look for you. I wonder if the others can tell.  36. Smith reaches for her, but she skips back out of reach.
It was never so before. Smith looks at her with love rising in his heart like the scent of a crushed herb. Her heart is a nest, untouched b grief.
Can it be that wa have met again? That I can look again into your ayes -- hold you again in my arms at last? And I so changed -- so different! Have I answered you -- have I come to you?
(in a whisper) Yes...No, it is not you. {after a moment) Is it you?
Say it again, my sweet. Speak. I cannot live or breathe until I.am next to you, and I can feel your hand.
I waited -- watched -- so many days --

And 1 treated you so unkindly! Ah, my guardian angel, my light in the darkness, how I hate myself for giving you pain! There is something I know when I am with you that I forget whan I am away. Tell me, my sweet, did you wish me to come back and liva with you again?
{suddenly afraid) You must not look into my eyes. You must not touch me.

I must hold your hand when I speak with you. He at last has found a passage to the other sea. He steps up to her and touches her belly. She is ~~ so open, so unafraid. He bobs like a cork on the ocean of her movements.  64 65 66 57. EXT. TREES OVERHEAD - SMITH’S AWAKENING The world spins to a stop The moon peers at Smith thr : 7 ough the pines. Flecks of moss drift down from the upper $ branches.
We can’t go inte the forest. Could I show you England? I would take cara of you, I promise. I would never be a brute to you. But no, it is too far. You would perish there.

If I can be with you, that is all. He gazes at her. She is a lady, a flower, a jewal. The woods murmur about them. He looks out on a new creation; landscape as lovely as a lost Eden. O his America, his ne found land, how blessed he is in discovering her, and in full nakedness; unbound. The curtain is lifted, and he sees with the eyes of his soul. But even as he does, and: knows this is what he has always bean waiting for, strivi for, he fears that he might be overwhelmed -- that he mig not be equal to what he has known but disintegrate under its pressure. There is a temptation to rush back into the comforting darkness of his former life.
Smith has no luck trading at a nearby camp. Huddled in their fur robes by a blazing fire, the Indians point to t sky. Soon winter will ba here.
On his way back to the boat, Smith runs into one of the English sentries.

What are you doing here? ” SENTRY I beg your pardon, sir. You were gone longer than wa expected. Appears I let myself wander a bit. Things go badly? I am gone two days, and you fall right back into your old ways! What has been going on here? Didn’t I tell you to dig a new well -- farther from the river? Why hasn’t this bean done? The wind flows in melody through the sky~loving treas. . Pocahontas looks up.

The winter snow tumbles down, veiling the fort and the fields beyond, the woods and rocky shores in white, seemi nowhere to alight. Smith watches, too, as the English wander around in the grip of malaria and blackwater fever, raving like madmen, Epidemic has done in more than half of them, starvation t rest. Brawls erupt over food and small possessions. The settler boil their belts and harnesses and eat them. They commit murder for matches. They eat dogs, cats, even rats. But civilization, aven such as it exists, begins to work its effect on Smith. Every one of his compatriots is an avenu that leads him back into his former ways of thinking. Wilf, the cabin boy, cheers him with memories of youth an home.
Are you happy?
Why showldn’t I be?
What makes you happy?
The sunshine. The sky at night. But especially, I likes it when things goes my way.

My eyes -~ how green, how green! Asking all these questions! Smith laughs, The domestic intimacy of the fort brings hi around and makes the magic city and even Pocahontas seem unreal. Did he really make lova to her, really promise to take her away to live with him? The notion that ha could make her his mistress fills him with a sort of horror, ev while it still whips and stings his blood. He wonders wha came into him. He feels he has been awful, then in the Next moment that his behavior was quite sane.
Sir, Ackley’s dead. And, directly, somebody ate his hands.

(pilfering Ackley’s things) Went out in the ‘eight of style, anyhow. Such tranquility -~ look at him! You'd think he could speak, His hands have been chopped off and taken for food. Tha sight of it turns Smith’s stomach. SECOND SOLDIER . I shall miss him. I think we all shall. SMITH . Bury him. And put this in the morning report.

Again he thinks about her. Ha agonizes over what he shoul do. Only a few months ago, ha held her to him under the blue strong sky, kissing her eyes and lips. He gasps, swept by this rush of remembrance, and is back with her again, back in the rapture of his kisses on her upturned face of innocence and humble passion, back in the suspens and beauty of that pagan night, He looks around him. What would the others think of such wild, unlawful loving? He wonders if he really loves her, or if he only wants her because she is so pretty and lova him,

The English line the walls of tha fort. Beyond it lies a sight to astonish them. Pocahontas is leading a. great procession of Indians toward the gates -~ braves with carcasses of dear and braces of turkey slung from poles over their shoulders, women with large reed baskets of cernbread and raccoon.
Pocahontas and Smith find themselves alone for a moment a the English fete their red saviors, overwhelmed by this gratuitous act of generosity.
They all bow to you. The President! My father will not let me bring you anything more. He says we hardly have enough for ourselves.
IT understand.
I will do what I can. -’ SMITH Don’t put yourself in danger. You neadn’t do anything more ~- for us.

If your people are hungry, they can find shellfish under the ice. Pocahontas looks puzzled. Smith casts about for the thing he wants to say. What doas he risk doing to her? Don’t trust me.
Why do you say that?
You don’t know who I am,
Of course I do. John. Why shouldn't I do anything I can for you? I love you. I like to show you that I do. Does it make you uncomfortable when they see you with me?
Sometimes.
: I would be near you. You know that e from the way I look at you, don’t you?
Yes. Yes I do, my love.
Why have you not come to me?
Thera are people dying around me here.

I know it is a terrible thing to say, but how can you stay with them, John? They’ re so fierca. They’re so dirty, too, No wonder they dia. (after a silence) What can.you have to do, lova? Living at the fort, Smith has come to see things with English eyes again. Her age and her openness, the very things that he treasures, embarrass him somewhat. He remembers that at certain times he adores her; at other times he can hardly recall who the person was that felt this way. He is aware of a new world, a reality whose existence he never had guessed or penetrated through to. The whole scheme of his former life has been called inte question and seams to him now like an illusion. But that does not make it any less problematic; rather far more so  ps 78 64.
Does your mother speak with you still?

Yes. She speaks in silence, like the stars. And if I do not answer, she says, “What could I say to you that I have not told you in my own language? Is it my fault that you have net understood ma? You think I wished to speak to your eyes and ears, and it was my heart that spoke to you. In truth, it was the heart.of all the earth that spoke to you through mine.” She is not here, but up there -- far!
She is dead and cannot hear you. Speak with me, dear -~ I am living and can answer.

The English give the Princess a round of applause as she leaves, Passing back through the gates of the fort, Smith comes to a stop. Wobblahead, the lunatic Indian whom Smit met long ago in the longhouse at Rerowocomoceo, has come the fort during the night and is entertaining the men. Smith watches as the fool, an axcellent mime, pretends to mount an imaginary beast. One by one, the colonists break into laughter. They seam to know nothing of Smith’s romance and would not aven hold it against him if they di They respect him; they depend on him.

He’s coming to England with us! Tf ‘ave agreed to become his manager. I expect I shall soon be entertaining divers offers. Wobblehead nods and points over the seas, England’s direction. A suspicious dog answers in the distance. The crowd melts away. It is their uneasiness, more than anything else, which causes Smith to ask if they were amusing themselves at his expense. Ha strides around, as though looking for a confrontation. Why should he feel any tie to this sorry lot and their selfish plans?°
You, what were you laughing at?  79 80 81 65.
Why, I can't be sure. An idea that I ‘ad in me ‘ead, Did I offend, sir? I must be going. I got me chores. He slinks off. Smith wonders how much he knows.
Pocahontas walks along with a frown. What is she to make of Smith’s words?

location: A CORN FIELD NEAR THE FORT

text: Spring has come, bringing sunny weather. Indian scouts sneak up to a field near the fort, a sunken enclosure camouflaged with vines, They strip the vines back and peer inside. Befora them stand row upon row of qreen shoots six inchas high -- baby corn plants. The Indians’ leader darts inside and uprocts one to take back to the Emperor. INT. POWHATAN’S LODGE Powhatan tosses the corn plant down in front of his daughter. His voice is soft and loving.

They do not mean to leave. ({pausa) This does net surprise me. What does is how they found the seed and: where to plant it. This the Tassantasses do not know. And how did they find the other things -- the oysters, the turkeys’ aggs? When Pocahontas starts to speak, he cuts her off. He does not require an answer to these questions.
He will forget you.
Have you no kind word for me, father?

No. She jumps to her feet and leaves.  83 84 85 86 87 66. EXT. POWHATAN’S LODGE Powhatan throws open the door of his lodge. Opechancanou and the Chiefs of his Armies understand him and, with a * great shout, repair to their units.

A singla native scout observes a cross standing in the midst of the wilderness. Then, coming into sight of the fort, he solemnly plants three arrows in the road outside ita walls, to serve warning of tha Emperor's intentions. The English are by now accustomed to strange antics from the Indians and give the business no thought.
Spearing gophers? The Indian reaches into a pouch, mumbles an incantation a casts a handful of dust in the sentry’s direction.

Powhatan casts tobacco leaves on the streaming grey water of the Chickahominy, to satisfy himself that the omens ar good. The camps are a hive of silent activity as tha Indians prepare to make war. Braves plunge their spears into a log, working up their courage with whoops and crie They put on paint and smoke tobacco, say prayers and bid goodbye to their children. Allies gather from distant camps. Streams of warriors become whole rivers. Pocahontas looks on with alarm.

As dusk settles, Pocahontas walks around Werowocomoco, shivering like a frightened deer. INT, POWHATAN’S TEMPLE ~ DUSK Powhatan has come to his principal temple to meditate before the sacred hearth. The dancing firelight gives him the appearance of a great conjurer.
Find my daughter. A brave clacks a hollow log.

Pocahontas hears the drums. Suddenly, she makes a decision.  88 ao 90 67. With an air of nonchalance, she ambles through the main gate into tha tobacco fields beyond. onl YGols see hes cov ry miy the great wooden Looking back from the cool dark rows of tobacco, her kinsmen seem to her like people she knew in some time lon Past. With a sob rising to her throat, she turns off into the woods. and runs

Pocahontas crashes through the mocnlit woods in a panic. The pinas sway back and forth like a wild sea. She stops for a moment ta listen to the drums, but they only harden her determination, and she starts running again.
Pocahontas wakes up the English sentry at Jamestown.
The Princess!
Please get him! Hurry!
You won’t say that I was drowsing, will you, Highness? No sooner did TI shut me eyes than I was lifted out of this wretched world and forgot me duties!

head_text.subj: EXT, A FIELD BEYOND THE FORT

text: Smith leads Pocahontas inte a field of leveled ground beyond the fort. The twisted shapes of burnt-out tree stumps loom up about them in the light of Smith’s hurrica lantern.
How do you know?
The corn. He sees you mean to stay. Do you? Do they? Smith does not.answer. She is terribly upset about what she is doing. ~
Make peace with him before he comes.  68.
‘2 won't accept peace. He'd be a fool O.
You're going to fight a war with him? Send them away. So many will die!

IT won’t de that. They wouldn’t listen to mea avan if I did. Why should they? This earth is theirs as much ag it’s yours, You own it, I know. Well, I suppose you could say you’va owned it long enough. Now othars are having their turn, (after a pause) Besides, they have no boats to leave in. She is steadfast in ignoring the drift of what he says.
We can go away. Wa can go where nobody could find us.

Where? For how long? We can’t live out in the woods. And the truth is I could never take you to England with ma, either. You don’t belong in that world, You’d be like a plaything. A curiosity. They make you over there. They make you their own. They press you small, lika Chinese feat. Smith looks off into the woods. All at onca it strikes hi how terribly he has compromised har -- and that now he mu take a stand.
This isn’t you, John. Don’t you ramember? But when she looks at his face, she sees that ha remember nothing of those other times.
(shouting) Watchman! How many hours till the dawn?
(faintly) Two, Captain! Impulsively, Smith draws some beads and bells from a pouc on his belt and offers them to her.
Here. Bellis? She looks at him, unbelieving. He himself seems horrified at what he is doing,
Why do you give ma these?
You’ ve done the English a service.
Let mea see your face. -
They should be thankful to you. You have extended yourself for them -- now more than once.
(very proud) I have betrayed my father! Nothing can reward me for that. If...he saw me with these, he would take my life. Here. Take them back.
T can’t do what you wish.
They care nothing for you. I can stop my father. Tell them to leave.
They wouldn’t listen to me.
Never until this moment have you spoken falsely. Why have you said such things to me?
Truthful, pure as you, I cannot he.  91 70.

I know that you would never deceive me. I ran here through the forest. Now I feal I’ve dona somathing very wrong. (horrified) Will you warn them? Suddenly he regrets his cruelty. He takes her by the hand
You have to come with me.
Where?
Inte the fort. Your people will know you came. They’1ll find out soon enough. POCAHONTAS . What will you do?

My sweet, my woodland fairy, my saviour, why do you fear ma? Do I now seem to you dark and evil, but too late for your peace, after the sweet sickness of love has infected you? He reaches out towards her, but she wrenches free and retreats to the edge of the woods, stopping now and then look over her shoulder in a proud, confused way.
Stay! I must not let you go alone. They will punish you, When hea starts toward her, she turns and runs away.

Smith follows her. She is like some little dog which has lost its master and dees not know whether to run on, to r back -- where to turn. He seems on the verge of coaxing her back when he sees a squad of Indian scouts advancing through the woods. He hides behind a tree. When he looks back, she is gone. He has no alternative now. He turns back. Meanwhile, Pocahontas abandons herself to her grief.  92 93 94 95 7h.

Smith walks back into the fort. He cannot think clearly. He does not know where his duty lias or whether ha even cares anymore. He wonders what has made him change. He remembers making vows to her, but they seem like the word of a stranger.

Captain? Is anything wrong? Excuse ma if I worry too much, but the ships should’ve been ‘are weeks ago, and now the men are talking -- ‘ave they forgot about us? Smith stares at him a long time before speaking. Shall he obey the voice that in the forest commanded him? Shall he live in this world or that other?

Wake the men up. Silently. Have them . report here. Don’t stand there. Go! INT. SMITH’S TENT Smith throws himself on his straw bed. For a moment’s passion, he has cut her life to ribbons, perhaps sent her off to her death. What would it mean, going to her now? It would be madness. Then, the memory of the poor, bewildered figure, of those anxious eyes, digs into him again. In a seizure of longing, the kind that comes upon one when life seems to carrying something out of reach, he leaps up. He wants he again; her kisses, her soft body, her abandonment, all he warm, pagan emotion; wants the wonderful feeling of that night under the sighing pines; wants it all with a horrib intensity.
Smith walks out toward the woods beyond the fort.
Captain? The men are ready. What is it that struggles against pity and this feverish longing and keeps him rooted here? He turns back, He will think about it later.
As the sun rises through the cool blue canyons of the pines, Pocahontas wanders along in a daze.  96

Under the ganeralship of Opechancanough, the Indians move quickly through the woods until they have surrounded the ort. A scout slips up through the wet marsh grass to the palisade. At his signal, the Indian soldiers advance, brandishing their spears and war clubs. The English have been waiting for this moment. They roll out their cannons and send a sickle of grapeshot through the Indians’ front ranks. Astonished, the Indians fall back, but the second and thi waves press blindly on. Before tha English can reload, they are upon the walls. They fight with a blind determination, but their light weapons are no match for English steel. They retreat back into the field, where again they are beset by the cannons. Yet still they rally and make a second charge. Fresh troops constantly replace those who have retired. In the same way that the English pass orders by trumpets and drums, the Indians use herald to cry out when to attack and when to retreat. . When an Englishman falls, the Indians stuff arrows up his rectum and hack him to pieces, lopping off heads and hand and private parts, waving the trophies aloft, laughing. Musketeers advance into the field, each protected by a Pikesman. They rest their heavy weapons on a stand, then light off their hundred-caliber leads in a great cloud of smoke. Opechancanough is puzzled. How could the enemy have known of the attack, as clearly thay did? The Indians shout curses and accusations of betrayal at Smith in Algonguin. He does not reply. His comrades look to him for an explanation. With his sword and bullwhip, Smith ranges out beyond the fort to engage in single combat. Tears stream down his face. His eyes are crazy and ferocious. He shrugs off his wounds. He proves himself the bravest of the English, a law unto himself. © Powhatan, sick at heart, watches the progress of the batt from a cliff half a mile from the fort. Things do not go well for the Indians; they are used to fighting in ambush and skirmishes, not pitched battles. Still, they vastly outnumber the English and hope to wear them down.

Pocahontas watches the Indian wounded being taken to the rear. They bear their sufferings in silence.  97 73. She wanders about in a turmoil of shame and bewilderment. She cannot go back to her father -- what should she do? How many yet will die on her account? Her cousins and brothers look questioningly at her, knowi she likes the English but hardly guessing the full extent of what they would consider her treachery. Suddenly she sees her brother Parahunt among the wounded. A piece of shrapnel has torn through his belly; he will n survive.
Something stung me, then I couldn’t walk. Now I can’t move my shoulder, sister. I’m cold. Cold!
Here, rest. Help him!
Sit down. Talk to me. Thera’s nething you can do.

Don’t say that. Wait. Help him! She runs off to lock for help, but she does not get far. Two Indians seize her on order from the Emperor. They ignore her protests -- that her brother is dying, that he father will punish them when he finds out how they have treated har.

The attack seems to have abated, though a few Pamunkey braves steal into the fortress through chinks in the wall and tunnels they have dug. They fight blindly with knives and tomahawks until they are contained and killed. Lookeuts search the horizon. Smith knocks them from their parch. “ SMITH What are you looking for? There’s no one coming to rescue you. Flecked with blood, he walks through the stockade, sneeri at his soldiers. BEN . You seem pretty ‘appy.  98 74.
Nothing intoxicates ma like disaster. My past mistakes seem very small, A wounded man pulls an arrow from his hand and waves it hysterically at Smith.

T‘m not entirely sure I shall have tha use of this hand again. I liked it while I had it. You sea, I was a clerk when I left London. I never thought I’d have any trouble with it. Don’t walk off. What was they shouting at you? (Smith turns around) You heard me! Don’t give ma that poxey look. What did you do to them? What did you do to gat them so oggly about us? Why ‘ave I got to pay for it? (Smith dees not answer) He’s not telling us something, and I got a right to know. They won’t respect our white flag. They won’t receive our emissaries. There’s something he’s not telling us! ‘ SMITH Stupid as hogs, the lot of you.
Now we're fighting with each other, When the anemy’s out there preparing to cut our throats! Smith strides around, bristling with contempt.

Stupid as hogs. {under his breath) Always shut up somewhere. Wobblehead, who knows no sides, gives Smith an apologetic look. It is not in his nature to be sad for long, however He leaps in the air and runs off through the lanes, hooti maniacally. INT, SMITH’S TENT Smith sulks in his tent like Achilles, Has he betrayed he from a fear of his peers’ opinions, he who prides himself on bending to no man? What need has he to justify himself to the likes of them?
39 75. A man with his fine sense of. honor cannot forgi i . give himself for acts that lesser men might consider trivial. Ben enters,
You must be more diplomatic.

What have I got to say? I can’t bring my tongue to say it. What should I do? Show them my wounds and tell them how I gat them in their service, while they ran from tha noise of their own drums. Hang ‘em. I’d rather die than crave their favor.
They say you mock them. When our patrols returned unharmed, you expressed your regret. You call ‘em enemies of true nobility. SMITH . Yes. .
Why do you want to lead them?
I deserve to. ©
You have no desire to?
I have no desire to trouble the poor with begging. Maybe you can give me a box on the ear so I may look penitent.
Take care they don’t plant a deep enough rage in you they make you one of their own. Smith walks outside. The Indians have broken off their attack.

Stripped to his underwear, Smith plunges into the river. The puzzled looks of the English give him an odd pleasure He swims farther and farther out, defying the danger of t fast current and the hostile Indians on the other bank.  100 101

To go back and love Pocahontas in the woods, with everything around wild and fitting -- that, he knows, is impossible, To transplant her to a great town; to keap in some little room one who belongs so wholly to nature -- h shrinks from this, In London her very simplicity, her lac of all sophistication, would make her life a misery of exile and alienation. But now that she is gone, he hates bimsel£ and the English, with their smug ideas of right a ty . An ache for lost youth, a hankering, a sense of wasted lo and sweetness, grips him by the throat. Surely, on this earth of such wild beauty, one is meant to hold rapture t one’s heart as the earth and sky hold it. And yet it seem that one cannot, or not for long. What did he do that was wrong? Where is that new world in which he found such happiness? Those woods, with their sk loving pines? . EXT. POWHATAN’S CAMPAIGN TENT Pocahontas is conducted to Powhatan’s campaign tent by an official of the court. Shae takes a moment to compose herself before she enters. She knows her father is aware of her offense.

Pocahontas sits bafore Powhatan in the hazy darkness of t tent. The Emperor is thickly painted and oiled all over - his arms and shoulders red, his face blue, his body jet black. From his ears hang the dried claws of a kingfisher

You've brought me great sadness. You could have married other chiefs and worked for your nation, You could have helped to bring us peace. You have forgotten your duty. (pause) So have I. I loved you more than my people. I put you, my heart and soul, ahead of them. I did that thing which I forbada you to. You have been a fool, but I have been a very great fool. These peopla come to take our world away. We must defend ourselves against them. Many more will die because of our folly. I shall tell nobody of this. Not because I love you but because I am weak.
From outside come the noises of new preparations for battle.
I can no longer speak with my ancestors, nor with my people. Someday, if I have any honor, I shall tell them what I have done and offer them my life. Today I cannot.
Forgive me, father!

You have been the light of my life. I cannot give you over to die. I banish you instead -- I take your nama away and send you to your uncle. I am too old to see you die, but if I see you again, I might feel the love of you again. You are already dead. I . cannot love one that is dead. I cannot love a ghost. So leave me now, ghost girl, and may the Father of our people give you happiness in the hereafter. Pocahontas stands up. He sits with his head bowed. Despairing of a further word from him, she leaves.

The Indians hold a ceremonial funeral for Pocahontas at a pavilion near the battlefield. Once the joy of her people’s eyes, they will no longer look at her except in their mirrors. They behave as though they genuinely believed she were gone -- a ghost. Still, the ritual is one to befit a princess. Heralds pla dirges on trumpets of tree bark. Eight strong braves bear the palanquin that will carry her off to exila. Two hermaphrodites walk ahead with fans at the ends of long poles, to protect her from tha sun.
An English scout sees Pocahontas’ train moving through th woods. He recognizes her.
Tomocomo has come to Smith as a spokesman for Powhatan, h emperor. They are alone in the moonlit woods.  104 78.

The great Powhatan speaks thus: “You, destroyer of peace, a man I saved, and sheltered, and fed -- treated like a son! -- have you not injured me enough? You have stolen my child’s heart from me. With a thousand inventions you have driven her mad. With your lying tongue you have changed her into a demon to persecute me.” I was to say no mora, but see -- Catching hold of the top of a sapling, ha hends it to the ground.
We shall treat you in the same way. He turns and leaves.

At dawn the Indians resume their attack. They twist moss around the points of their arrows, seat them alight and shoot them ovar the walls of the fort onto the thatch roo ef the English houses, which burst into flame. The English rush around trying to put out the fires. Thei situation grows more desperate from hour to hour. A soot- blackened soldier reports ta Smith.
The east wall is burned through, sir. Wa cannot close it without exposing ourselves to their missiles. Argall leads in the scout who spotted Pocahontas in the woods. :

Tell him. “SCout The Princess is up the river at Pastancy. They sent her to her uncle Patowomeck, Lord of the Naked Devils of that region and, by the by, an acquaintance of mine. So I gat to talking to his Nibs and he proposes to sell her. He says with her at the fort, the Emperor will not dare attack us. He dotes on her.  79.
You’re certain she’s the one you saw?
With these eyes! I spoke to the King directly.

And what does this regue propose to sell her for? scout iowas getting to that. His most favorite thing is combs, but in this case he appears to have his heart set on a kettle. A hob, you know -- a copper kettle, like me mother uses for making tea. What use he means to make of the instrument I cannot say.
Well? SMITH . We don’t take hostages. King James would not approve.
¥ou would rather see us annihilated? It is the first direct challenge to his authority that Smith has faced.

She has done enough for us. She risked the beating out of her own brains to save mine. She kept the rest of you from starving. We shall not answer her kindness by making her a captiva. Argall presses Smith, confident the others are on his sid that they will see this as their last hope.

She and her flock are on the verge of killing us all. I expect there will scarce be a handful alive whan the boats return, if they ever do. You told us yourself that her father regards her as no one else. (Smith says nothing) Do you have private reasons for this attitude of yours?
Return to your post. Smith’s behavior feeds the flame of Argall’s suspicions. He stands his ground.
The penalty for disobeying an order of the Prasident is hanging. You’re breaking the laws. This is mutiny.

Me breaking the laws? You've broke them all yerself, as fast as you made them, (to the men) I have information Smith here was Planning to marry the wench and make himself King of Virginia! I have the proof! The crazy one told ma. Listen to what he says! Fearing their wrath, Wobblehead retreats into the shadows Smith strides up to Argall until they are face to face. His eyes blaza with anger.
Strike me and you break the laws of this colony. Those are the laws! You’ve got to protect thase men.
Strike you? He looks at him for a moment, than reaches out and gives his ear a violent twist.
Jesu! Suddenly, six of Argall’s cohorts fall on Smith from behi and wrestle him to, the ground.

(triumphantly) You're no longer in command, Smithy. I shall have the medal now, You have been derelict in your duties to the King. You/’ve betrayed the citizens of Jamestown. The medal, please! You’ve shamed the investors of the London Company. I therefore pronounce you unworthy of being a member of this colony. (MORE )
105 106 107 108 81. ARGALL (cont/’d) As Chief Spokasman for His Majesty in the New World, I sentence you to corporal punishment until you admit your guilt.
Smith is conducted to tha decks by a brace of guilty Soldiers. Among them is tha santry who greeted Pocahontas the morning of the first attack. He has reason to feel guiltiest of all.
Sorry, Captain. We must do as Argall says. Wea men ‘ave got no power.
I advise you to admit your fault. Otherwise hea will kill you. He can’t afford to be considered a mutineer, without legal authority.
Smith is keelhauled -- dragged by a rope beneath the ship so that his back is raked along the jagged barnacles encrusted on the hull. He bobs to the surface, gasping fo breath.
You want to say your piece? No? Very well. I sentence you to hard labor at the brickworks.
Argall and a party of ten soldiers sail the shallop upriv to kidnap Pocahontas.

PATOWOMECK, the traacherous King of Pastancy, watches out of tha side of his aye as an English sailor sets a copper kettle down in front of his lodge. He must be careful not to appear complicitous with the kidnapping.

No use trying to hide her. I know she is here. Help me, and I will be your friend! Patowomeck’s ayes flit nervously around. Argall bows to Pecahontas, who is surprised that he seems to know who sh is.
Who sant the boat?
Why, nokedy sant it, milady. I was just passing by whan I thought it diplomatic te stop and pay a visit.
You don’t saem like someone to trouble himself about diplomacy.
(slyly) Does Captain Smith?
I could not say. I am sure he does not tolerate insolence from his subordinates. Two Moons, a sympathetic Pastancy Indian, appears heside Pocahontas and bows to her. They are out of Argall’s hearing.
Princess, they mean to get you on board and kidnap you.
What makes you say that? But there are tears in her eyes. She knows full well what is going on.
I saw your uncle dealing with. the Tassantasse. They’re planning to take you back to their camp. Watch out!

Nonsense! Pocahontas looks at the shallop, its mast wobbling back a forth in the lazy current of tha Chesapeake, Could Smith really have sent it? Could this be a grand gesture from her lover? Tha music hints at such a-hope. Should she swallow her pride, betray her father yet again and give Smith another chance? She cares nothing for her dignity anymore. She is ruined. What is left to save -- except, if possible, a last glance at ona who once loved her? Patowomeck’s wife approaches. Her guile is heart- wrenchingly transparent,  109 110 83. PATOWOMECK’S WIFE Please come. I am afraid to go all by myself, My husband told me I could go only if you go with me,
You think it will be safe? PATOWOMECK’S WIFE Of course. You live in our house. We take cara of you. Pocahontas smiles pleasantly.
PATOWOMECK’S WIFE You go first. Pocahontas walks up the gangplank ahead of the wife.

You see? All at once the English seize her, pull the gangplank aboard and shove off. A display of their muskets is enoug to discourage the Indians from retaliating, though a few throw rocks and spears. Pocahontas feels a rudeness in Argall’'s grasp that tells her she is not being brought t Jamestown as a guest of the President’s. Now she starts t struggle in earnest.
You won't be hurt, Highness.

You wouldn’t dare! On tha shore Patowomeck rushes about giving contradictory orders, never letting go of his kettle, bristling with indignation, yelling words of encouragement to Focahontas and knocking his wife about. The English soldiers laugh, no longer able to keep up their end of the charade. Pecahontas covers har face with her hands. She burns with shame.

As the shallop drifts along the river, the English raider study their captive sympathetically. They know they owe their lives to her and that they have caused her to suffe terribly in return. Argall comes up beside her and drapes a shawl over her bare shoulders.  111 112 a4.
My father will not ransom me. Ha doas not feel toward me as he did before. I tell you this so you do not risk the lives of your man further than you already have.

One must hope, Your Majesty, I apologize for this discommoding of your person. Such are the necessities of war. (philosophically) I came out here because I had nowhere else to go. They took away my land, though I owned it outright and had papers to prove it. My father told me honor wasn’t going to help me get it back. And it doesn’t help you in the grave. He was wrong about all alse, but right about that.
O Mother, has he sent this ship for me?
Disembarking at the Jamestown docks, Pocahontas is dismay to find that Smith is not on hand.
Where is the President? The English, knowing that their fate may depend upon her, treat her with great deference.

President? Yes -- I neglected to tell you. The Captain’s no longer occupying that post. He can explain the reasons better than I. You will only be kept here long enough for us to arrange a truce. In the meanwhile I hope you won’t mind being -- looked after. He neds at a guard cof pikesmen.
Argall conducts Pocahontas through the streets. Wobbl ehe bows to her.

as. 113 INT. REVEREND WHITAKER’S HOUSE - MONTAGE Pocahontas enters the Reverend Whitaker's clapboard house the single frame dwelling in the colony. Her guards take up their posts outside. Slats have been nailed across the windows. She looks distractedly at the English appurtenances -- th oil lamps, the white pine furniture and the porcelain figures on the mantel. MARY, Whitaker’s maid, a middle- aged woman from Devon, appears to greet the royal guest. Great. care has been taken to ensure that she will be comfortable,
This will be your room, milady. Pocahontas acts as though she did not hear her.
She says that’s not her name anymore. She has no name.

How unfortunate! Well, wa shall have to give you one. Perhaps...Lady -- you are of royal blood -- Rebecca! My mother’s name was Rebecca. Would that be suitable? Does she like it? You may leave us, Captain. Argall leaves, Beneath a single window there is a bed of rough planks covered with a pallet of straw. Pocahontas’ guards stroll back and forth outside. Mary can plainly se that she is utterly distraught and crazed with grief.
This is the basin, for when you want to wash. The water is outside the window, in the rain barrel. She demonstrates the use of the wash basin.
This is soap! She shows Pocahontas by pantomime how the soap is used. There is not a trace of pleading or complaint in her gues She appears determined to face each new hardship with courage. :
I think you are most elegant, excusing the liberty. .  114 115

Mary tries to get her to eat, but she will not take food. Mary gives her a bath. She is limp and indifferent even a a pail of hot water is poured over her shoulders. She is like a wild animal that has been brought into captivity. She puts on Mary’s cast-off clothes. First a corset, then a tattered camisole, then a long calico gown. Mary makes her look at herself in the mirror. She is beautiful, yet Mary’s cries of admiration do not cause he to feel less forlorn. Mary shows her how to sit and walk like an Englishwoman. She must keep her back straight and her knees together, smoothe out her skirt, etc. Outside a new battle rages.

Go ahead. Take.a few steps. Walk. That’s right. The shoes hurt your feet, don’t they? Pocahontas’ movements; naturally free, seem constrained i these new garments. They weigh on her like papal vestments. But she continues to accept Mary’s efforts to teach her English ways with a fierce stoicism., If this i to be the form of her damnation, sha will throw herself into it head first. She will relish her perdition.

The Indians pelt the fort with flaming arrows as the English, their defenses crumbling and their walls on the verge of being wholly breached, wait to see if Pocahontas will ransom them. Then, all at once, they leave off their attack, and we stand with Powhatan as they behold with astonished eyes t return of Newport and the English ships.
Mary shows Pocahontas how to use a door key. It seems to her that the Princess’ mind has been damaged.

Not that way. Hold it like this. (abruptly) Will you see Captain Smith? Pocahontas does not reply. Pity for Smith’s approaching sufferings at her hands surges up inside her together wit a smaller measure of pity for herself. Outside they hear loud, boisterous noises.  117 118 119 ay.
Mary rushes out to sea what is going on. Pocahontas lingers inside, her heart pounding with expectation. Cannons thump in the distance. English soldiers rush through the streets, celebrating wildly.
What is it?
The ships ‘ave come. The war’s over. The Chief of the Savages has offered us peace.
Pocahontas chops her hair off with a broken conch shell.

Your dear mother, Rebecca, fell ill in our outward passage, at Gravesend, a small fishing town at the mouth of the Thames, where the river flows out into the sea.” Opechancanough bursts out of a cottage, screaming in a wi Pamunkey way. Thomas Rolfe peers at his mother through a crack ina bedroom deor. The young lady attending him, a fisherman’s daughter, inspects the glass frog. YOUNG LADY . She gave you this? Very expensive. Remember her, dearie! Tears stream down Rolfe’s face. Pocahontas lies in bed, surrounded by a radiance of white linen.
